Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 39322  
December 2006 
 
 
 
Community of Practice on Managing for Development 
Results – Phase II
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Director General  K. Sakai, Strategy and Policy Department (SPD) 
Head  B. A. Purdue, Results Management Unit, SPD 
   
Team leader  G. Li, Advisor, SPD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Over the last several years, many developing countries in the Asia and Pacific region 
have begun to pursue results-based management approaches in national strategies and public 
sector management. To address the Managing for Development Results (MfDR) capacity and 
incentive issues at the working level in these countries, the Asian Development Bank approved 
a concept paper and subsequently a pilot small-scale regional technical assistance (SSTA) to 
support establishing a Community of Practice on MfDR (CoP-MfDR) in the Asia and Pacific 
region.1 The proposed regional technical assistance (RETA) has been formulated based on the 
experiences and lessons learned during the implementation of the SSTA.2 
 
2.  In November 2005, ADB approved an SSTA, on a grant basis, for the preparation and 
pilot of the CoP-MfDR. The activities of the pilot phase included (i) launching the CoP-MfDR in 
the  Asia  and  Pacific  region,  (ii)  establishing  an  IT-supported  virtual  learning  network,  (iii) 
conducting online discussions among CoP members, and (iv) reviewing the pilot operation of 
CoP-MfDR and making recommendations for its future.   
 
3.  The CoP-MfDR was launched in late March 2006. After the six-month pilot operation, it 
was reviewed in Singapore in early September 2006. All participating CoP members reiterated 
their strong commitment to sustain this new initiative and requested ADB to continue its support 
in facilitating its activities for the next 3 years. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.   
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The CoP-MfDR was designed differently from conventional capacity building approaches, 
particularly in four aspects: (i) it is driven by the demand of MfDR practitioners in developing 
countries, (ii) it operates mainly through the virtual learning network, (iii) it is a vehicle for peer-
to-peer learning among working level MfDR practitioners, and (iv) it is informal.  
 
5.  The CoP-MfDR launch was attended by 50 participants from 12 developing countries 
and development partners. Through the event, the CoP members (i) established mutual trust 
and the collegial atmosphere needed for online collaboration, (ii) learned to use the tools of the 
virtual  learning  network,  (iii)  explored  some  common  issues  to  be  discussed  further,  and 
(iv) formulated  an  action  plan  for  the  pilot  operation.  The  Coordinating  Committee  of  CoP 
members was also established to take up the leadership of CoP-MfDR with a management 
team in ADB’s Results Management Unit (SPRU).  
 
6.  The structure of the CoP-MfDR is composed of four layers: (i) 5 Coordinating Committee 
members from Mongolia, Nepal, Philippines and Viet Nam, with co-chairs from Mongolia and 
Philippines;  (ii)  about 30  core group  members  from  developing  member  countries  (DMCs) 
including Bangladesh, Cambodia, Fiji Islands, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Malaysia, 
Mongolia, Nepal, Pakistan, People’s Republic of China (PRC), Philippines, Tajikistan, Thailand, 
and Viet Nam; (iii) about 20 members from development partners including ADB, World Bank, 
Department for International Development of the United Kingdom, Organisation for Economic 
                                                 
1  The concept paper was cleared by the managing director general on 15 June 2005 and was included in the 3-year 
Asian Development Bank-wide (ADB) knowledge and product services work plan for the years 2006—2008. Prior 
to the submission of this concept paper, SPRU was given an allocation of $150,000 in early 2005 which was used 
to fund a pilot study approved in November 2005 on the viability and effectiveness of establishing a Community of 
Practice on Managing for Development Results. 
2  The technical assistance (TA) first appeared in the ADB Business Opportunities on 27 November 2006.

2 
Co-operation and Development-Development Assistance Committee (OECD-DAC), Lee Kuan 
Yew School of National University of Singapore, and results management experts worldwide; 
and (iv) about 100 registered members from the Asia and Pacific region and the rest of the 
world, who form the peripheral group.  
 
7.  The virtual learning network3 is the main feature of the CoP-MfDR. During the pilot 
period from April to September 2006, four expert-led online discussions were conducted:  
 
(i)  challenges, issues, and experiences of results-based management;  
(ii)  linking planning and budgeting;  
(iii)  establishing a results-based monitoring and evaluation system; and 
(iv)  MfDR in the context of the Asia and Pacific region. 
 
During the discussions, over 100 comments with diverse views were posted on the discussion 
forum.  Eighteen  country  case  papers  were  uploaded  online  and  discussed  among  CoP 
members. Of them, five (from Malaysia, Mongolia, PRC, Thailand, and Viet Nam) were included 
in  the  second  edition  of  the  MfDR  Sourcebook,  the  definitive  MfDR  tool  for  development 
partners.4  
 
8.  The CoP discussion forum contributed to very open exchanges, with considerable “give 
and take” between members. The personal contacts and mutual trust established during the 
face-to-face events contributed to the overall ambiance of openness and provided for further 
exchanges  of  experiences.  Most  members  exhibited  a  strong  interest  in  learning  and  felt 
comfortable raising challenging questions. They were frank in acknowledging problems faced. 
Many CoP members believe that CoP-MfDR can support the “diffusion of innovation” in the 
region, help members to confirm what they have been doing, and cause them to reflect on some 
possible changes. A number of well-known international experts contributed enormously to the 
online  discussions  by  providing  papers,  leading  discussions,  stimulating  the  debate,  and 
responding to questions. Their contributions were highly commended by the CoP members.   
 
9.  One of the features of the CoP-MfDR is that it is driven by the demand of the CoP 
members. During its pilot operation, the Coordinating Committee defined the CoP-MfDR’s own 
interests, and formulated the parameters for a dynamic and sustainable CoP. ADB’s role is to 
create an enabling environment by using its resources to bring together and support CoP-MfDR 
members as they articulate their own vision and action plan. The CoP-MfDR management team 
in ADB has been responsible for CoP’s day-to-day operations, i.e., coordinating and moderating 
its  online  activities  and  face-to-face  events.  Within  ADB,  the  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development Department (RSDD) and Office of Information Systems and Technology (OIST) 
provided support in establishing an online collaboration system to serve as the platform of the 
CoP-MfDR; regional departments and resident missions identified the core group members from 
their respective developing countries. Externally, CoP-MfDR operations demonstrated strong 
partnerships among development partners. To harmonize MfDR activities in the Asia and Pacific 
region, ADB and OECD-DAC jointly sponsored the CoP-MfDR Review and Mutual Learning 
                                                 
3 The discussion forum is in the virtual learning network of the CoP-MfDR with the following Internet address, 
(https://cop-mfdr.adb.org).  
4 The MfDR Sourcebook is an annual reference publication sponsored by the OECD-DAC Joint Venture on MfDR. It 
is published in hard copy and accessible via a website (http://www.mfdr.org/Sourcebook.html) that hosts examples 
of country cases and captures new material as it becomes available. The second edition of the MfDR Sourcebook 
will be issued in early 2007.

3
Initiative5 Meeting hosted at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy in the National University 
of Singapore from 30 August to 1 September 2006.  
 
10.  During  the  Meeting  in  Singapore,  CoP  member  Dr.  Sohail  Amjad  from  Pakistan 
presented an independent review of the CoP-MfDR’s pilot operation. He noted progress made 
in the membership and operation of the virtual learning network, emphasized the advantages of 
the CoP-MfDR compared with traditional capacity building approaches, as follows: (i) the CoP-
MfDR  can  better  reflect  the  voice  of  working  level  practitioners  from  developing  countries 
because of its style of free speech and informality; (ii) the CoP-MfDR can conduct dialogue in a 
more sustainable and timely manner; (iii) the CoP-MfDR can help MfDR practitioners to build 
stronger relationships over a prolonged period and establish a deep foundation of trust and 
understanding; and (iv) the CoP-MfDR is cost-effective since, after initial capital investment, the 
recurrent cost is negligible compared with benefits achieved.  
 
11.  Dr. Sohail Amjad and other CoP members also highlighted a number of issues that 
need to be addressed in CoP’s future operations: (i) the CoP-MfDR must be demand-driven, 
with a critical mass demonstrating a  need and desire for MfDR; (ii) discussion topics must be of 
mutual interest, relevant to most CoP members, and focused on common issues; (iii) CoP-MfDR 
needs to pilot a country-based or subregional MfDR network to scale up its impact to a broader 
base; (iv) CoP-MfDR should link to higher political policy makers to get their support on MfDR; 
(v) to the extent possible, CoP-MfDR needs to address language and digital divide barriers 
experienced by some members to broaden its outreach; (vi) CoP-MfDR needs a dynamic, 
persuasive, and skillful manager; (vii)  CoP-MfDR needs high-quality expert(s) who can provide 
sustainable and timely expertise, as well as helping to capture, consolidate, and disseminate 
MfDR knowledge and good practices; (viii) CoP-MfDR should itself be results-oriented and 
monitored  and  evaluated;  and  (ix) as  a  regional  public  good,  CoP-MfDR  needs  continued 
financial and administrative support from ADB.  
 
12.  The  pilot  CoP-MfDR  has  triggered  interest  from  the  international  development 
community. During its pilot period, some developing countries and development partners in 
Africa and Latin America regions have asked the CoP-MfDR to disseminate its experiences. 
They see it as a good channel to strengthen the capacity of the developing countries and are 
considering establishing their own CoPs on MfDR in the near future.    
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The main purpose of the CoP-MfDR is to address the challenges of implementing MfDR 
in DMCs and help them to improve results-based management in the public sector. The RETA 
will continue supporting the CoP-MfDR to make it useful and sustainable in strengthening MfDR 
demand and capacity in DMCs.  
 
14.  Over time, the CoP-MfDR, facilitated by ADB and supported financially through RETA 
funding, should lead to (i) enhanced demand and capacity for MfDR in DMCs, (ii) identification 
and dissemination of good practices, and (iii) development of a mutual learning network that will 
help CoP members improve their own skills in results management. 
                                                 
5 The Mutual Learning Initiative on MfDR was launched in October 2005 and sponsored by the OECD-DAC. It 
focuses on a series of workshops that are proposed to be held in Asia, East/South Africa, West Africa, and Latin 
America. Once the four events have taken place, the initiative will use different ways to disseminate the lessons 
globally.

4 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The expected outputs of the RETA are (i) a sustained regional CoP-MfDR with a critical 
mass  of  results  practitioners  at  the  working  level;  (ii)  established  country-based  and 
subregional-based  MfDR  networks;  (iii)  publication  of  CoP-MfDR  good  practice  papers, 
consolidated questions and answers, and contributions to the MfDR Sourcebook; (iv) a stronger 
and more effective CoP-MfDR Coordination Committee; and (v) a tool to monitor and evaluate 
CoP-MfDR operation.  
     
16.  The RETA is designed to address the issues that have arisen from the implementation of 
pilot SSTA (see paragraph 11). Activities include (i) facilitation of CoP-MfDR online discussions; 
(ii) sponsorship of the CoP-MfDR annual meeting; (iii) together with other development partners, 
sponsorship of a MfDR training hub in the Asian Pacific region and the annual MfDR training 
programs;  (iv)  support  of  the  coordinating  committee  in  leading  CoP-MfDR  operation;  (v) 
support of the establishment and activities of the country-based and subregional-based CoP-
MfDR;  (vi)  development  and  update  of  the  MfDR  Virtual  Resource  Center  and  member 
countries’ MfDR folders; and (vii) assistance to some members in addressing their language 
and connection problems by providing translation and technical support.  
 
17.  The CoP-MfDR annual meetings are designed to complement the online activities and 
strengthen mutual trust among CoP members. It is projected that the annual meeting will be 
held each year in one of the CoP member countries. The 2007 annual meeting is planned to be 
held in the Asia-Pacific Finance and Development Center located in Shanghai, PRC. The 
guiding criteria in selecting participants for the annual meeting will be based on the participation 
of CoP members in online discussions.  
 
18.  Based on priorities agreed by the CoP members, in partnership with other development 
partners, the RETA will support the establishment of a regional training hub in MfDR and 
provision of training programs for MfDR practitioners in the region. High quality trainers will be 
invited to introduce MfDR experiences, good practice, tools and methods, and conduct the face 
to face dialogues with CoP members on practical MfDR issues. Participants could come from 
national and sector government officers, civil societies and academes in the region. A diagnostic 
training needs assessment and work plan will be completed as part of the CoP-MfDR action 
plan. On the action plan for 2007, the CoP members agreed that the main theme would be a 
“results-based M&E system on the ground”.     
 
19.  The RETA will also be used to support selected country-based or subregional-based 
CoPs based on demand from the members. This is relevant for those CoP member countries 
with similar results-based management issues in the same language. Currently, the Philippines 
and the PRC are planning to establish their own country-based CoPs, while some South Asian 
countries have indicated their intention to establish their subregional-based network.          
 
20.  The RETA will support the broadening of CoP-MfDR outreach programs to a wider 
audience. This may include (i) publishing selected CoP-MfDR papers, (ii) inviting CoP members 
to present their MfDR experiences at relevant international conferences, and (iii) translating 
MfDR  documents  and  some  background  materials  to  facilitate  the  CoP  members’  broad 
participation in online discussions.   
 
21.  Based on their need, the RETA will also be used to assist Coordinating Committee 
members in leading and monitoring CoP operations. One of the tools for the Coordinating

5
Committee is the CoP-MfDR balanced scorecard which will be developed in early 2007 and can 
be used to report the CoP-MfDR operation to its members regularly in the future.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
22.  The total cost of the RETA is estimated at $750,000. The RETA will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s technical assistance funding program. Details of the cost estimates are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
23.  ADB—through its Results Management Unit (SPRU), in consultation with RSDD, OIST, 
regional departments, and resident missions—will be the executing agency of the RETA and will 
be responsible for overall management and monitoring of the activities.   
 
24.  The RETA will be implemented over 3 years, commencing in January 2007 and ending 
in December 2009. The RETA will need two individual international consultants with up to 
31 person-months  of  consulting  services.  They  will  be  recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (April 2006, as amended from time to time). The outline 
terms of reference are in Appendix 3. 
 
25.  High quality, experienced international expert(s) will be recruited to help direct the online 
discussions and capture, consolidate and disseminate the MfDR knowledge learned during the 
CoP-MfDR operation (about 9 person-months). The selection of the expert will be subject to the 
agreed  annual  theme  of  discussion.  For  2007,  an  expert  in  results-based  monitoring  and 
evaluation will be engaged.  
 
26.  Aside  from  the  expert  who  will  lead  the  online  discussions,  another  international 
consultant is expected to be recruited as CoP-MfDR manager. The CoP-MfDR manager will be 
responsible for liaising with Coordinating Committee members, responding to queries ranging 
from technical to community logistics, updating the MfDR resource center and country folders, 
improving the design of the CoP-MfDR website and discussion forum, facilitating country-based 
and subregional-based CoP activities, drafting the CoP-MfDR monthly newsletters, linking the 
CoP-MfDR virtual learning network with other MfDR regional CoPs, and so on.  The CoP-MfDR 
manager will work up to 22 person-months. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
27.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Community of Practice on Managing for Development Results – Phase II, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will engage two international individual consultants 
for  the  regional  technical  assistance  (RETA).  Based  on  the  findings  of  the  Community  of 
Practice on Managing for Development Results (CoP-MfDR) pilot review, the RETA will require 
(i) an international consultant to help direct the online discussions and capture, consolidate, and 
disseminate the knowledge of MfDR; and (ii) an international consultant to act as the CoP-MfDR 
virtual learning network manager. 
 
A.  International Consultant to Direct Online Discussions (9 person-months)  
2.  The RETA will engage an international consultant to act as the CoP-MfDR expert. The 
consultant will help facilitate the online discussions and capture, consolidate, and disseminate 
the knowledge gained during the online discussions. The consultant’s specific tasks include the 
following:   
(i)  Support  the  CoP-MfDR  discussion  forum  by  designing  online  programs, 
providing comments, responding to questions, stimulating members’ participation, 
and  suggesting  results-based  management  materials  that  are  posted  for 
discussion. 
(ii)  Introduce  international  experiences  on  results-based  management,  including 
those from Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) 
countries, developing countries, and development partners. 
(iii)  Attend the annual meeting of the CoP-MfDR for face-to-face discussions with 
CoP members on issues tackled online, and hold MfDR clinics with participants 
on a topic selected by CoP members.  
(iv)  Based on the CoP members’ needs, the consultant will be requested to work with 
CoP  members  on  selected  research  papers  addressing  results-based 
management issues, specifically in the Asia and Pacific region.    
 
3.  The consultant should have global experience in results-based management, especially 
in  developing  countries,  with  practical  experience  working  with  the  CoP  members  and 
introducing the results-based management approach to practitioners in the Asia and Pacific 
region.  
4.  Up to a maximum of 3 person-months of work will be required each year for the next 
3 years.  Based  on  the  CoP  members’  need  and  the  theme  in  focus  each  year,  different 
consultants with different expertise may be recruited. Allowance will be provided in accordance 
with ADB’s practice and applicable rate to cover out-of-pocket expenses to be incurred by the 
expert, and actual expenses for any travel required to complete the assignment. 
B.  International Consultant, CoP-MfDR Manager (22 person-months)  
5.  An  international  consultant,  who  will  act  as  the  CoP-MfDR  manager,  will  also  be 
engaged. The CoP-MfDR pilot review indicated that a CoP-MfDR manager, who is responsible 
for  the  day-to-day  operation  of  the  virtual  learning  network,  is  crucial  to  the  effective 
implementation of the community.  
 
  9

10  Appendix 3 
6.  The international consultant must be a self-starter, hands-on problem solver, and team 
player with a minimum of 5 years experience in information and knowledge management with 
international organizations, preferably a multilateral development bank in the Asia and Pacific 
region.  The  consultant  will  have  graduate-level  education  in  public  policy  or  business 
administration, with a track record in developing content or as an editorial consultant for online 
journalism,  in  English.  The  consultant  must  be  fluent  in  English.  Writing  samples  will  be 
requested. Computer skills must include: Microsoft Word, Excel, Windows Explorer, Lotus Notes, 
Internet Explorer, HTML, CSS, and desktop publishing and graphics software. 
 
7.  Specific tasks include but are not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Organize, conceptualize, compile, and write the web content, in a lively and user-
friendly context. 
(ii)  Research and propose posting of information on MfDR, internally and externally, 
and to the CoP by posting on the website. 
(iii)  Ensure that all linked content on the CoP website is correct and accurate. 
(iv)  Write a monthly newsletter to publish on the CoP website. 
(v)  Liaise with participating resident missions and members to provide in-country 
support/ technical backstopping to CoP members to sustain online services. 
(vi)  Help prepare the documents for the annual CoP-MfDR meeting. 
(vii)  Prepare the discussion notes during the face-to-face meetings. 
 
8.  The CoP-MfDR manager is expected to provide consulting services of up to 22 person-
months.  However,  the  contract  will  be  on  an  annual  basis  so  that  Technical  assistance 
supervising unit may change the expert if needed.
